slide.title: Tools
slide.p: The following software tool are required in order to perform administrative tasks.

itemlist.title: SSH
itemlist.p: Required in order to login remotely to the server.

li.p: Included on most other operating systems.

itemlist.title: Subversion Client
itemlist.p: Required to manage files versioned by the CMS and contents of the Admin repository.

li.p: Windows: TortoiseSvn 1.6.x (http://tortoisesvn.net/) or the official command-line client.
Command-line client included on most other operating systems.

itemlist.title: LDAP Browser
itemlist.p: Required to manage the OpenLDAP directory (might not be used when integrating with a corporate directory service, e.g. Active Directory).

slide.title: Admin Repository

itemlist.title: The server has a special repository called Admin containing:

li.p: Server configuration, supporting scripts and branding.
Optional: Development of document types and style sheets.

slide.p: The Admin repository is located at the URL: http://server.company.se/svn/admin.

note.p: The path http://server.company.se/svn/admin/cms/ is checked out to the server file system at location /home/svnuser/cms/. Beware that the automatic updates to the file system is very sensitive to password changes, file system permissions, local modifications etc (subject to customization on each installation).

itemlist.title: Access permissions are defined in a Subversion Access File.

li.p: The syntax is described in Version Control with Subversion: Path-Based Authorization
The file can be edited via a Web browser on this URL: http://server.company.se/svn/admin/auth/access.accs.
The file is located on the file system here: /home/svnuser/cms/auth/access.accs. It can be edited with a text editor, e.g. nano.

note.p: It is highly recommended to use the group definitions in the Access file rather than assigning permissions to usernames.

admon.p: A syntax error in the Access File will revoke all permissions from the server, i.e. a server lockdown. Never edit the Access File without first ensuring SSH access to the server.

slide.title: Repository Administration
slide.p: Subversion repositories can be added and removed individually on the server.

li.p: Ensure that access permissions are correctly set up for the repository.

slide.title: Indexing
slide.p: All authoring data is stored in the Subversion repositories, however, the indexing server is required for usability and search functionality.

note.p: Re-indexing can be performed as required without loss of data. A large repository can take significant amounts of time to re-index.

admon.p: This information is preliminary and future development might simplify this process.

itemlist.title: The Arbortext Editor Deployment feature is typically used for:

note.p: Refer to the section Deploying a centralized configuration in the Arbortext Help Center for details.

li.p: All deployment data is stored in: http://server.company.se/svn/admin/deploy/.
This location MUST be configured with anonymous read permission. This can be verified by pointing a web browser to the URL which should display without prompting for login.
The CMS is normally delivered with a standard deployment setup in: http://server.company.se/svn/admin/deploy/default/
After setting the environment variable APTDEPLOYPATH to http://server.company.se/svn/admin/deploy/default/, the Editor should, on restart, download the deployment packages and configurations.
Bursting rules are configured for each document type.
There is one collection of bursting rules for each repository, located in /arbortext/bursting/.
There MUST always be a bursting rule file called atidefaults.xml. This bursting rule should not be edited except on recommendation from Simonsoft.
Each bursting rule file should be named after the document type it applies to, and given the extension .xml.

Property naming is very liberal, as long as the namespace convention is followed.
